div1.p: McClure discusses defensive preparations being made in the county should Confederate troops cross into Union territory. He also writes about an upcoming election.

div1.head:
Franklin Repository Office,
Chambersburg, Pa.
div1.p: I called together half a dozen of our leading & most prudent men, and submitted your letter. They have sent out for one of the Co. Commissioners a very prudent man (brother of Jim Scotts) and will have him and several of the Town Council in a confidential consultation tonight.

I am perplexed as to what course to adopt. If the Rebels come they will come much stronger than
before, and I doubt not with a much more destructive . Our raiders south have been wantonly destructive with private property and the lex talionis may come back upon us.

We will at first arrange for communication with a telegraphic instrument at Greencastle. London and a few good scouts on the view, we may avoid surprise, and thus save much valuable property. In connexion with the Hagerstown, Greencastle, Mercersburg, Williamsport and Hancock people, we can I think arrange a perfect police system, and
be able at this point to have timely notice of any movement.

The Governor will fail at Washington I fear, Staunton is so bitterly against him that he will interfere against any movement the Governor may desire. He seems to be actuated all the time by the impression that Gv Curtin is only seeking popularity in all these efforts: and he does not particularly deserve to be popular.
Write me daily how things look. You need not fear any sensations from any facts or opinions you may give for we shall be careful of all that.

I fear Curtin is assenting an in-tarily to the use of his name for renomination. If Franklin is nominated on the 17th every consideration of prudence will dictate his peremtory withdrawal and under any circumstances it is of much more than doubtful wisdom.
